awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Plant Genome Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Laura Lee is "Cell cycle and cell identity regulation are linked during regeneration" The host institution for the fellowship is New York University and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Kenneth Birnbaum.

Plants have incredible regenerative capacity. Through regeneration, plants can rebuild lost organs and entire plants can be regrown from single plant cells. Clonal propagation, in which clones of plants are produced via regeneration, is a critical agricultural technique. It enables stable transmission of desirable traits in crops that might otherwise be lost through sexual reproduction. Further, it is a necessary step in some techniques used in crop engineering. However, not all varieties of plants from the same species regenerate with the same efficiency. Additionally, many important crops do not regenerate well, including maize and wheat. Improving regeneration capacity in important crop species will allow for crop optimization to combat food insecurity due to climate change. The goal of this work is to uncover the mechanism underlying differential regeneration capacity among maize varieties. Pursuit of this research will provide postdoctoral training opportunities in working with cereal crops like maize, including studying complex crop genomes and root development. The broader impacts of the project are focused on increasing access to academic and research careers for scientists from underrepresented communities through undergraduate mentorship programs. In addition, the activities funded in this initiative will support participation in the New York University department of biology’s antiracism task force, which will improve support for current and future trainees from underrepresented backgrounds.

The long-term objective of this research is to elucidate the epigenetic regulation of regeneration capacity in crop plants. The work will test the hypothesis that dynamic changes in chromatin regulate a tradeoff between regeneration and defense and is motivated by several key findings: (1) cell cycle advancement and histone acetylation remodeling are both required for regeneration, (2) changing chromatin accessibility regulates regeneration capacity, and (3) altering the defense vs. regeneration response, hypothetically controlled at the chromatin level, can improve regeneration. The research takes a unique strategy to uncover the differences in chromatin regulation between maize varieties with known differences in regeneration capacity. Chromatin will be profiled in distinct cell cycle phases and over the course of successive cell divisions to determine how cell cycles alter chromatin during regeneration. Additional experiments will monitor chromatin remodeling over the course of a regeneration assay using high-regeneration (Hi-II) and regeneration-recalcitrant (B73) Zea mays lines. Candidate genes identified in these approaches will be functionally characterized in Zea mays. The work will produce genome-wide datasets that reveal a mechanism that identifies key regulators of differential regenerative capacity. As such, this work will answer longstanding questions about the connection between cell cycle and chromatin while producing tools to improve regenerative capacity in recalcitrant crops. 

Keywords: regeneration, chromatin, cell cycle, Zea mays, Arabidopsis thaliana, epigenetics, histone acetylation

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plants’ ability to regenerate lost organs is central to their survival as sessile organisms. Plants use this ability to survive hazards that cause physical damage such as herbivores because they cannot move away from such threats. Plant regeneration is also a requirement for core agricultural techniques like grafting and tissue culture. Despite the apparent importance of plant regeneration, there is still much to learn about how regeneration works at the molecular level. The root tip is an exemplary model to study regeneration in plants. Stem cells can be manually excised, which induces fate-specified cells to reprogram back to stem cells in order to replace the lost stem cell population. The goal of this project was to characterize the relationship between fundamental aspects of plant regeneration: cell type reprogramming and cell division. Specifically, this project sought to test the hypothesis that cellular reprogramming required cell division to reset a key regulator of cell identity, chromatin. While the findings of this project did not identify changes to chromatin that were dependent on cell division, this work did identify a relationship between cell division and a molecule called glutathione (GSH) that is key for controlling regeneration. Overall, this project was highly successful, leading to publications in high impact journals including a first author publication by the supported fellow in Developmental Cell. It also supported several key career development activities including invited talks presented at conferences and collaborations across institutions.

In order to characterize the relationship between cell cycle regulation and cell identity changes during regeneration, it was necessary to achieve improved insight into transcriptional regulation of the cell cycle. In service of that goal, the fellow generated large transcriptional datasets that described the cell cycle in plants that maintained developmental and cell type information. This was accomplished using single cell RNA-sequencing of root tips that were chemically enriched for different phases of the cell cycle, providing enhanced cell cycle information on a cell type specific basis. These datasets resulted in the first set of large transcriptional markers of G1 phase of the cell cycle, which had been previously difficult to characterize. The datasets generated for this project indicated GSH metabolism was enriched during G1 phase of the cell cycle. In parallel, the development of a long term time lapse imaging system led to the identification of unique regulation of G1 phase length during root tip regeneration. By combining manipulations of GSH content in roots with long term time lapse imaging it was determined that a spike in GSH nuclear levels following root tip injury triggered coordinated, fast cell cycles that are necessary for regeneration to proceed efficiently. These results establish a novel mechanism for coordinating the cell cycle with tissue damage in plants and suggest a more profound role for metabolites like GSH as developmental regulators.

The broader impacts of this project were accomplished through two main efforts. First, several undergraduate students were trained during the project, two of whom came to the lab as part of exchanges with other universities. One of these students accomplished a sufficient body of work to earn authorship on a paper as an undergraduate student. All of these students have since gone on to the next steps in their scientific careers. Three students pursued graduate education in the sciences, while one has moved on to a career in science industry. Second, the fellow participated in outreach activities such as volunteering with the organization BioBus, which makes science learning experiences accessible for students across the New York City area.
